{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3225907,"name":"Daniel C.","username":"Daniel1464","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/6bbea6/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-08-22T00:56:46.898Z","cooked":"

Looking at the pathplanner repo, I see that there’s a lot of new changes that aren’t aligned with the current PathPlanner java library. Is it possible to use the current beta version of the library instead? In particular, our team really appreciates the autoBuilder functionality with differential drivetrains, and we need it this year for the offseason tournament(as next year, we’re switching to swerve).

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-22T01:10:42.440Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":70,"reads":279,"readers_count":278,"score":405.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"Daniel C.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56324,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3225928,"name":"Nadav","username":"Gold87","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gold87/{size}/191382_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-22T02:20:03.719Z","cooked":"

At the moment I assume not. There hasn’t been any official announcement from the creator of PathPlanner so it is likely still in its development phase. Since the newest commits are called “2024 Reworks” I’m guessing the new features will be available by next season.

Generally before competition it is best to not make any big code changes since it leaves uncertainty if things will work the way they are expected to on the field.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-22T02:20:03.719Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":268,"readers_count":267,"score":73.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"Nadav","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57374,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"353 Alum | Elastic"},"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/2","custom_user_title":"353 Alum | Elastic","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3225930,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-22T02:39:15.414Z","cooked":"

Big issue for using it at the moment is that it’s built against the current WPILib development builds, so it’s not compatible with any 2023 robot projects. You’d have to copy the source into your project and make a few changes to get it to work.

I’d really recommend against trying to use it for any competitions unless you really know what you’re doing and have a plan to fall back to an old version if you need to. It’s still pretty in development and not fully tested to a level I’d be comfortable with yet. A lot has changed.

I will typically try to aim for actual beta releases around the same time that WPILib starts doing theirs, so you can expect it around then.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-22T02:39:15.414Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":246,"readers_count":245,"score":129.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"Michael Jansen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33850,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3015 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/3","custom_user_title":"3015 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3225972,"name":"Dalton Smith","username":"Daltz3","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/daltz3/{size}/145991_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-22T13:45:37.616Z","cooked":"

I saw that PP is switching from RAMSETE to Pure Pursuit. What’s the rationale behind this decision?

From my understanding, Pure Pursuit has problems toward the end of the trajectory without some hacky fixes.

In the 2024 Rework is python support coming / planned? We are contemplating a change from C++ to Python now that it is officially supported but may stick with C++ a little longer if 3rd party libs aren’t adding support yet.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-22T15:41:18.366Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":173,"readers_count":172,"score":44.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"kylelanman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9953,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3226097,"name":"","username":"Vasista","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/ccd318/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-08-22T16:45:51.390Z","cooked":"

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-22T17:49:55.431Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":157,"readers_count":156,"score":46.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"kylelanman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://robotpy.github.io/projects/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Robotpy Projects · RobotPy","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9953,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3226364,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-23T02:02:10.911Z","cooked":"

Not completely set in stone yet but it’s what I’ve been working with. If it doesn’t end up working as well as I’d like I might look at other options but it’s been working pretty well so far.

There’s a lot of reasons I currently like using it, but they pretty much all stem from the ability to do on the fly “generation” instead of generating all path states ahead of time.

So, if you get hit off course by another robot it will be able to react gracefully and get back on track instead of over correcting and going max speed to get back to what the state should be at that point in time.

Another reason this is really useful is that paths don’t need to have a known starting state. You can follow a path from a standstill right at the start point, far away from the start point, halfway through the path already, or driving full speed into it and the controller will handle it. Nice for automated scoring systems so it can gracefully take over from a human driver, or for pathfinding into another predefined path.

This also makes pathfinding a lot easier to work with. You can just take a list of points and follow them instead of having to worry about using them to create a continuous path, then generate all the path states with it.

Also, the PPLib implementation of pathfinding uses AD* so the path it’s trying to follow can be updated as it gets further refined in the background. So the pure pursuit controller is able to easily handle that switch.

Finally, tuning the controller doesn’t really seem necessary at the moment (there will still be the ability to do so), so getting it up and running is much simpler and faster. Ramsete is pretty much like this too so this is mainly and advantage over the holonomic controller.

A bunch of other reasons/plans for the future but that’s the gist of it.

kylelanman:

In the 2024 Rework is python support coming / planned?

I think I’d like to do an official python implementation if python support is official in 2024. I haven’t seen anything concrete about that yet, just that they were planning on it but I might have missed it. But, since there would likely be python bindings from the robotpy folks it’s not a huge priority at the moment.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-23T02:02:10.911Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":148.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"Michael Jansen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29225,"username":"Daltz3","name":"Dalton Smith","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/daltz3/{size}/145991_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33850,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3015 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/8","custom_user_title":"3015 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3226549,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-23T16:14:02.766Z","cooked":"

I fundamentally disagree with pure pursuit’s controller methodology. I think a trajectory controller should be offered too. Here’s why I dislike pure pursuit:

  1. It doesn’t offer direct control over heading (or in the case of swerve, the velocity vector).
  2. If the robot is already on the path, it won’t stay on it around corners due to the lookahead point. This is a fundamental feature of pursuit controllers that can’t be fixed completely. It’s problematic in the presence of obstacles.
  3. Because the robot deviates from the path all the time, it’s harder to meticulously plan where the robot goes.
  4. It has unstable behavior at the ends of paths that has to be worked around by stopping the controller early or artificially extending the trajectory via the tangent to the last waypoint.
  5. It doesn’t let you enforce dynamics constraints on the path, or have much control over the time domain response of the robot at all.

Essentially, instead of trajectory and controller tuning, you now have to do path tuning to make the robot do what you want.

mjansen4857:

There’s a lot of reasons I currently like using it, but they pretty much all stem from the ability to do on the fly “generation” instead of generating all path states ahead of time.

So, if you get hit off course by another robot it will be able to react gracefully and get back on track instead of over correcting and going max speed to get back to what the state should be at that point in time.

Spline trajectories can be replanned on the fly, even with kinematic and dynamic constraints.

mjansen4857:

Another reason this is really useful is that paths don’t need to have a known starting state. You can follow a path from a standstill right at the start point, far away from the start point, halfway through the path already, or driving full speed into it and the controller will handle it.

Since you need odometry for the correction to work anyway, you know the starting point. You could replan the trajectory instead, which can be cheap. Alternatively, given a pose+velocity controller in the chassis coordinate frame, you could adjust the ratio between the x and y position gains to change the robot’s approach.

mjansen4857:

This also makes pathfinding a lot easier to work with. You can just take a list of points and follow them instead of having to worry about using them to create a continuous path, then generate all the path states with it.

This goes back to my difference in philosophy: I want to control exactly what my robot is doing at all times.

mjansen4857:

Finally, tuning the controller doesn’t really seem necessary at the moment (there will still be the ability to do so), so getting it up and running is much simpler and faster.

It does leave performance on the table though. In general, a feedback controller arbitrarily deviating from the path would be considered poor controller tuning; pure pursuit does that on purpose.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-23T16:15:11.422Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":128,"readers_count":127,"score":210.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/9","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3226675,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-24T00:58:48.255Z","cooked":"
calcmogul:

This goes back to my difference in philosophy: I want to control exactly what my robot is doing at all times.

I think this is pretty limiting. There’s really no way to handle deviations from a trajectory without handing off control of the robot to some algorithm. Whether that’s pure pursuit or some algorithm that replans a trajectory, if your robot starts a path with an undefined state then you need some way to get it back on track.

Pure pursuit may not be the final solution here, but it is the one that currently works. If I can find something better I will probably use it. But, I think overall it is currently better than the old version simply because of the flexibility it provides. If I can do something that has that flexibility without the inaccuracies of pure pursuit I’ll do it. I have a few ideas they just need to be tested.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-24T00:58:48.255Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":107,"readers_count":106,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"Michael Jansen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33850,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3015 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/10","custom_user_title":"3015 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3226698,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-24T02:53:36.867Z","cooked":"
mjansen4857:

I think this is pretty limiting. There’s really no way to handle deviations from a trajectory without handing off control of the robot to some algorithm. Whether that’s pure pursuit or some algorithm that replans a trajectory, if your robot starts a path with an undefined state then you need some way to get it back on track.

I think there’s a miscommunication here, but I’m not sure what it is. It seems like we’re working from different vocabulary and mental models.

To explain the framing I’m familiar with, a control system has:

  1. A state estimate
    a. Where the robot thinks it is right now
    b. Can be determined via odometry, computer vision, some combination
  2. A reference
    a. Where the robot should be right now
  3. A time-domain trajectory
    a. How the robot should get from the current reference to some future reference (which I’ll call the “goal”)
  4. A feedforward controller
    a. Computes the input required to get the robot from the current reference to the next reference
  5. A feedback controller
    a. Computes an input to steer the robot from the state estimate toward the reference over time

With this context, the state estimate is always defined, though it may not accurately reflect where the robot actually is. If it’s not accurate, pure pursuit isn’t going to help you either.

The feedforward does all the work when the robot is exactly on the trajectory, and the feedback steers the robot back on if it deviates due to modeling error or disturbances. Both are always running.

When I said “I want to control what the robot does at all times”, I meant the robot should follow preplanned time domain behavior, and converge to that preplanned behavior in the presence of disturbances or modeling error. This is beneficial for repeatability.

Here’s an example of what I mean using the algorithm from WPILib’s LTVDifferentialDriveController class:

Planning a new trajectory from the current state estimate would be even better in this situation because it would avoid backtracking, avoid actuator saturation, and be more repeatable in the time domain than a path following algorithm due to the feedback controller’s convergence properties.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2023-08-24T04:23:01.706Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":90.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":439982,"topic_slug":"is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":4,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/is-it-possible-to-use-the-latest-reworked-version-of-pathplanner/439982/11","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3226777,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2023-08-24T14:23:17.232Z","cooked":"

My initial approach was to replan trajectories, but that became very difficult as you need to find an optimal way for the new trajectory to join with the pre-planned one without doing anything weird, and find a balance of smoothness/driving time while minimizing the amount of the original trajectory you end up skipping.

But, I think I thought of a way to do so while I was typing up my experiences trying to do this… So I’ll go experiment with that again
